questions.text: Identify the following vector
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aedes Disease Causative agents Vectors Malaria Plasmodium (commonest) Plasmodium Anopheles mosquitoes Dengue fever Virus Aedes mosquitoes Encephalitis Virus Culex mosquitoes African sleeping sickness Trypnosomas Tse tse fly

questions.text: In a slum area of a city, due to heavy rains, the entomologist with a team of medical officers visits to prevent mosquito-borne disease. So they collect a sample of water containing eggs. A water sample is shown below. Sample most probably contains eggs of which mosquito genus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anopheles The Anopheles lays her eggs singly. The eggs are boat-shaped and possess lateral floats. The Cu/ex lays her eggs in small clusters or rafts; the eggs do not possess lateral floats. The Aedes lays her eggs singly; the eggs are cigar-shaped and do not possess lateral floats. The Monsonia lays her eggs in star-shaped clusters attached to the undersurface of the leaves of certain aquatic plants, notably the peseta plant. Tribe Genus Anophelini anopheles Culicini Culex, Aedes, Mansonia EGGS (1) Laid singly (2) Eggs are boat-shaped and provided with lateral floats (1) Laid in clusters or rafts, each raft containing 100-250 eggs (except-Aedes). (2) Eggs are oval-shaped and not provided with lateral floats. LARVAE (1) Rest parallel to the water surface. (2) No siphon tube. (3) Palmate hairs present on abdominal segments. 1) Suspended with head downwards at an angle to the water surface. (2) Siphon tube present. (3) No palmate hairs. PUPAE Siphon tube is broad and short. Siphon tube is long and narrow. ADULTS 1) When at rest, inclined at an angle to the surface (2) Wings spotted. (3) Palpi long in both sexes. (1) When at rest, the body exhibits a hunchback (2) Wings unspotted. 3) Palpi short in females.

Culex The Anopheles lays her eggs singly. The eggs are boat-shaped and possess lateral floats. The Cu/ex lays her eggs in small clusters or rafts; the eggs do not possess lateral floats. The Monsonia lays her eggs in star-shaped clusters attached to the undersurface of the leaves of certain aquatic plants, notably the peseta plant. (2) Eggs are oval-shaped and not provided with lateral floats. LARVAE (1) Rest parallel to the water surface. (2) No siphon tube. (3) Palmate hairs present on abdominal segments. 1) Suspended with head downwards at an angle to the water surface. (2) Siphon tube present. (3) No palmate hairs. PUPAE Siphon tube is broad and short. Siphon tube is long and narrow. ADULTS 1) When at rest, inclined at an angle to the surface (2) Wings spotted. (3) Palpi long in both sexes. (1) When at rest, the body exhibits a hunchback (2) Wings unspotted. 3) Palpi short in females.

questions.text: In a slum area of a city, due to heavy rains, the entomologist with a team of medical officers visits to prevent mosquito-borne disease. So they collect a sample of sewage water containing larvae. A water sample is shown below. Identify the sample contains larva of which mosquito genus

options.label: D
options.text: Can be any one of the above

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be any one of the above
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Can be any one of the above Anopheles lays her eggs singly. The eggs are boat-shaped and possess lateral floats. The Cu/ex lays her eggs in small clusters or rafts; the eggs do not possess lateral floats. The Aedes lays her eggs singly; the eggs are cigar-shaped and do not possess lateral floats. The Monsonia lays her eggs in star-shaped clusters attached to the undersurface of the leaves of certain aquatic plants, notably the peseta plant. Tribe Genus Anophelini anopheles Culicini Culex, Aedes, Mansonia EGGS (1) Laid singly (2) Eggs are boat-shaped and provided with lateral floats (1) Laid in clusters or rafts, each raft containing 100-250 eggs (except-Aedes). (2) Eggs are oval-shaped and not provided with lateral floats. LARVAE (1) Rest parallel to the water surface. (2) No siphon tube. (3) Palmate hairs present on abdominal segments. 1) Suspended with head downwards at an angle to the water surface. (2) Siphon tube present. (3) No palmate hairs. PUPAE Siphon tube is broad and short. Siphon tube is long and narrow. ADULTS 1) When at rest, inclined at an angle to the surface (2) Wings spotted. (3) Palpi long in both sexes. (1) When at rest, the body exhibits a hunch back (2) Wings unspotted. 3) Palpi short in females.

questions.text: The diagram shown below indicates which stage of the life cycle of mosquito
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pupa There are four stages in the life history of mosquitoes egg, larva, pupa, and a The pupa is comma-shaped in appearance, with a large rounded cephalotho a narrow abdomen. Two small respiratory tubes or trumpets project from the upper surface thorax. The pupa represents the resting stage in the life history of the mosquito; it feeds but prefers to stay quiet at the water's surface. Disturbed, it swims rapidly downwards into the water. The pupal stage lasts for 1-2 days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Larva The larva is a free-swimming creature with an elongated body divisible by int thorax and abdomen. It feeds on algae, bacteria, and vegetable matter and passes through fou of growth called "instars" with molting between each stage. Option: C . EGGS The Anopheles lays her eggs singly. The eggs are boat-shaped and possess lateral floats. The Cu/ex lays her eggs in small clusters or rafts; the eggs do not possess floats. The Aedes lays her eggs singly; the eggs are cigar-shaped and do not lateral float. The Monsonio lays her eggs in star-shaped clusters attached to the under of the leaves of certain aquatic plants, notably the peseta plant OPTION: D . Adult The body of an adult mosquito consists of three parts: head, thorax, and abd

questions.text: A team from the NVDCP goes to a survey in a rural area to identify water lodging places and clear them. Which type of control measure is it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Environmental control The aim of the environmental control measure is to eliminate their breeding. This is known as "source reduction." It comprises minor engineering methods such as filling, levelling, and drai breeding places; and water management (such as intermittent irrigation). Th proven methods of larval control.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Biological control In biological Control, we use small fish that feed readily on mosquito larvae. The best known are the Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (kn Barbados Millions). Option: C. Chemical Control Chemical control larvicidal are used like: Mineral oils Paris green Synthetic insecticides Option: D. None

questions.text: To prevent the breeding of mosquitoes in a lake or pound with fish, which is the best method to apply from the given below?
questions.correct_answer: B. Biological control with Paris green
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biological control with Paris green Biological control measures is the best method to apply in the pond with fish as anti-mosquito measures There is evidence that biological measures alone are not effective. So, it needs to be combined with other methods. Synthetic insecticides and mineral oil are harmful to aquatic life forms. Paris green is relatively less toxic to aquatic life forms. Hence, It is best to combine Biological control with Paris green

questions.text: Following rainfall in an area, the team from the Municipal corporation goes for space spray in public areas as a measure for controlling mosquitoes or as an anti-mosquito measure. Which chemical is most likely to be used in it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyrethrum Space sprays are those where the insecticidal formulation is sprayed in the atmosphere as a mist or fog to kill insects. For space spraying insecticide on a large, it should not have any residual effect Residual effect increases chances of resistance. The common space spray is Pyrethrum extract. For domestic purposes, a handgun with a fine nozzle is all necessary. For application on a large scale, power sprayers or "aerosol" dispensers are needed. Pyrethrum sprays are effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes. Reduction is only temporary due to the absence of residual effect, generally n for household purposes. As reinfestation from outside sources generally occurs within a short time. DDT is not recommended for large-scale larviciding operations because of the long residual effect, water contamination, and increased risk of dev resistance in vector mosquitoes. Malathion and Gamma-HCH are not recommended for large scale due to residual effects and increased chances of resistance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. DDT DDT is not recommended for large-scale larviciding operations because of long residual effect, water contamination, and increased risk of dev resistance in the vector mosquitoes Option: C. Malathion Malathion and Gamma-HCH are not recommended for large scale due to their residual effects and increases chances of resistance. Option: D. Gamma-HCH Malathion and Gamma-HCH are not recommended for large scale due to residual effects and increased chances of resistance.

questions.text: A man visits a doctor to complain of being bitten by an insect. He killed the insect and brought it to the doctor for identification. The killed insect is shown below. Identify the insect and which disease it cause
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kala-Azar The picture above Is of Sand Fly. Identification features are: The head bears a pair of long, slender, and hairy antennae; palpi and a proboscis. The thorax bears a pair of wings and three pairs of legs. The wings are upright, lanceolate in shape, and densely hairy. The legs are long and slender and out of proportion to the size of the body. The abdomen is covered with hair. Sandflies may be distinguished from mosquitoes by the following characteristics Size: Sandflies are smaller than mosquitoes. Wings: The wings of the sandfly are up-right and lanceolate in shape Legs: The legs of the sandfly are longer compared with the size of the body. Hairs Sandfly is a hairy insect. (5) Hopping: Sandflies hop about and make no choice Hence, from the above options, only Kala Azar is spread by sand flies. Mosquitoes spread filaria and malaria.

questions.text: A man visits a doctor to complain of being bitten by an insect. He killed the insect and brought it to the doctor for identification. The killed insect is shown below. Identify the insect and which disease it cause
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sleeping sickness Identification features of the Tse tse fly are: Generally resemble the common housefly. They are yellow or dark brown in colour, and measure about half an inch long. Their wings, when folded, overlap each other like the blades of scissors. They have a rigid and non-retractile proboscis adapted for piercing the skin and sucking blood.

questions.text: Of the two given figures below, Identify the correct statement

options.label: A
options.text: Insect shown in Figure 2 causes Tick typhus

options.label: B
options.text: Insect shown in Figure 1 causes Relapsing fever

options.label: C
options.text: Insect shown in Figure 2 causes Relapsing fever

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and b are correct.

questions.correct_answer: C. Insect shown in Figure 2 causes Relapsing fever
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insect shown in Figure 2 causes Relapsing fever Comparison of hard and soft ticks Hard ticks (Ixodidae) Soft ticks (Argasidae) 1. Scutum Covers the entire back in males; only a small portion in front in females. Absent 2. Head Situated at anterior end Lies ventrally; not seen from above 3. Spiracles Situated behind IV coxa Situated between III and IV coxa 4. Eggs Several hundreds. or thousands laid at one sitting Laid in batches of 20-100 over a long period 5. Nymphal stages One Five 6. Habits Cannot stand starvation: feed night and day Can stand starvation for a year or more 7. Diseases transmitted Tick typhus Viral encephalitis Haemorrhagic fever Tularaemia Tick paralysis Human babesiosis Relapsing fever 8. Important species Dermacentor andersoni Haemophysalis spinigera Ornithodorus moubata

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, malaise, headache, retro-orbital pain, and rash for 3 days. On Serological examination, it is diagnosed as a dengue infection. Which of the following is wrong about the vector of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The vectors are Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopticus

options.label: C
options.text: Transovarian transmission of the virus can occur

options.label: D
options.text: The mosquito, once infected, remains so for life

questions.correct_answer: B. Extrinsic incubation period is 2 days
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extrinsic incubation period is 2 days The extrinsic incubation period is an organism's time to develop in the intermediate host. The extrinsic incubation period for dengue virus is 8 to 10 days

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. The vectors for dengue virus are aedes aegypti and aedes albopticus Option. C. The genital tract of the mosquito gets infected, and transovarian transmission of the dengue virus occurs when the virus enters fully developed eggs at the time of oviposition Option. D. The mosquito get infected by feeding on a patient from the day before onset to the 5th day of illness. After an extrinsic incubation period of 8 to 10 days, it becomes infective and remains so for life.

questions.text: An 8 years old child is brought to the fever clinic by his mother with complaints of fever on alternate days, no diurnal variation but the episodes of fever will be associated with chills, rigors, and severe headache. You suspect malaria and collect blood smears for examination. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the slides collected?

options.label: A
options.text: Thick and thin films are collected.

options.label: B
options.text: Thick film is for species identification, and the thin film is for quantifying parasite load

options.label: C
options.text: Both films were prepared on single microscopy glass slide

questions.correct_answer: B. Thick film is for species identification, and the thin film is for quantifying parasite load
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thick film is for species identification, and the thin film is for quantifying parasite load Option: B. Thick film is used for quantifying parasite load, and the thin film is used for species identification

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Thick and thin films are collected for microscopic examination of malaria parasite Option C. Both thick and thin films are prepared on the single microscopy glass slide Option D. The sensitivity of microscopy is high, can detect malaria parasite at low densities.

questions.text: Cyclopropagative biological transmission occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malaria Biological transmission is of three types: Types of transmission Types of transmission Examples 1. Propagative Agents multiply in a vector without changing form. Plague, bacilli in rat fleas 2. Cyclopropagative Agents multiply and change form in the vector Malaria parasite in mosquito 3. Cyclodevelopmental Agent only changes form without multiplying in the vector filaria in culex

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought to OPD with a rash on his body, fever, and lymphadenopathy. The rash was absent on the palm and sole. The following vector was responsible for transmitting the infection. Which of the following is the Likely condition the patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidemic typhus In the given question, the clinical features of the patient like fever, lymphadenopathy, and rash on the body except on the palm and soles. The vector shown in the image is the head louse. The disease caused by head louse from the above option is A. epidemic typhus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. B. Fleas cause endemic typhus. Hence, it is not the correct answer. Option. C . Trombiculid mites cause scrub typhus. It requires the presence of chiggers and scrub vegetation. No, such history is provided. Option. D. RMSF- the rash will occur in the palm and sole, and a hard tick will cause it.

questions.text: A male patient comes with fever, lymphadenopathy, and rash on the palm and soles. The causative organism for the given condition is R. rickettesiae. Which image in the options represents the vector for the disease discussed in the following question?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

D In the given question, the organism responsible for the disease is R. rickettisiae. The disease caused by it is rockily mounted spotted fever. The vector responsible for this is the hard tick given in image D.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Image A represents a flea, a causative organism for endemic typhus. Option. B . Image B represents the louse that causes epidemic typhus. Option. C . Image C represents trombiculid mite which causes scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with fever, lymphadenopathy, and weakness. There was also a maculopapular rash on the body. On examination, the following lesion was present on the body. The man tells the doctor that he has been to Himachal Pradesh, around the sub-Himalayan belt, where an insect bites him at that place. Which of the following is the vector responsible for transmitting the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trombiculid mite The given clinical scenario represents the triad of lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular, rash and the image shows eschar at the site of the bite. Hence the diagnosis of this patient is scrub typhus . The causative organism for scrub typhus is Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is transmitted by trombiculid mite, which is present in the scrub forest or vegetation near the Himalayan belt. Hence, the correct answer is option B

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Hard tick transmits Indian tick typhus, tularemia, and KFD. Option. C. Ixodid tick- it transmits babesia and Lyme disease.

questions.text: A female came to OPD with complaints of lethargy, weakness, joint pain, and fever. She also complains of the following lesion, which appears and disappears only to appear at a new place. A clinical diagnosis was made. Which of the following vector responsible for transmitting this disease transfers another disease from the given options?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Babesiosis In the given question, the clinical feature and image depicting erythema migrans suggest the clinical diagnosis to be Lyme disease. The vector transmitting the causative organism, i.e ., Borrelia burgdoferi , is the ixodid tick. Other disease which can be transmitted by ixodid tick is babesiosis. Hence, the answer is option C.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Tularemia is transmitted by hard ticks. Option. B. Relapsing fever is transmitted by soft ticks. Option. D. Indian tick typhus is also caused by hard ticks.

questions.text: You have observed a recent surge of fever cases in your area and reported it to the local health authorities, who surveyed the reports and confirmed a malaria epidemic there. They ask for your advice regarding the mosquito control measures. Which of the following is an anti-larval measure for mosquito control?

options.label: B
options.text: Elimination of standing water surrounding houses

questions.correct_answer: B. Elimination of standing water surrounding houses
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elimination of standing water surrounding houses Option: B. Elimination of standing water surrounding homes decreases the mosquito breeding sites. It is an antilarval measure. Another antilarval measure is using larvicides.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Residual sprays like DDT and malathion kills adult mosquitoes Option: C. Space sprays involve the application of pesticides in the form of fog or mist. The ultra-low volume method of pesticide dispersion by air or ground equipment has proved to be effective and economical. It is an anti-adult measure Option: D. Use of repellents, protective clothing, bed nets mosquito coils is the individual protection under anti-adult measure

questions.text: Paris green is useful for killing:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anopheline larvae only Paris green or copper aceto-arsenite, is an emerald green microcrystalline powder, practically insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison Paris Green kills mainly the anopheles larvae because they are surface feeders. Bottom-feeding larvae are also killed when Paris green is applied as a special granular formation.

questions.text: People of your locality are worried about the harmful effects of DDT residual spray. You convince them that the benefits of the application of DDT far outweigh the hazards. DDT does not cause immediate death of mosquitos but takes several hours to kill. The residual action of DDT may last as long as ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1.5 years The residual action of DDT may last as long as 18 months, depending upon the treated surface. (1.5 Years) On mud walls, the prolonged action is decreased by absorption. A WHO expert committee pointed out that “there is no valid reason to discontinue the use of DDT, for application in houses, against malaria or other diseases because its safety for human use remains unchallenged despite the tremendous amount of research” It has been responsible for saving millions of lives throughout the world. No toxic effects have been reported in the past 20 years among 2 lakh spray men nor among 1000 million people living in repeatedly sprayed houses.

questions.text: You decide to spray this contact poison in your locality as a mosquito control measure. This contact poison contains 70-80 percent of the para-para isomer, which is its most active fraction. What is its dosage as a residual spray
questions.correct_answer: A. 100 mg per square foot area
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100 mg per square foot area DDT is the insecticide discussed here As a residual spray, DDT is applied at 100 - 200 mg per square foot area. The formulation of choice is a 5 percent suspension of DDT, which, when sprayed at a rate of 1 gallon over 1,000 sq. feet, gives a dosage of 200 mg per square foot. As dust, DDT is used in 5 to 10 percent strength to control lice, fleas, ticks, and bugs. In aerosols or space sprays, DDT is one of the main constituents. DDT is still one of the most widely used insecticides.

questions.text: You are a Medical officer and you notice that the wells in your regions are serving as a breeding ground for Anopheles stephensi. Which among the following insecticides can be used?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abate Abate is an organophosphorus compound used extensively in India to control A.stephensi in wells and domestic containers due to its low toxicity. Good results are obtained at a dosage not greater than one ppm Fenthion when applied at a rate of 1 ppm, is highly effective in controlling the larvae gans Dichlorvos is successfully used for disinfecting aircraft. It kills insects by fumigant action. Propoxur is a carbamate insecticide recommended as a substitute for DDT in areas where anophelines have developed resistance to DDT and dieldrin.

questions.text: The following statement about DDT is false:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediately kills the prey DDT is primarily a contact poison, acting on the nervous system of insects. It does not cause immediate death but takes several hours to kill. The residual action may last as long as 18 months, depending upon the treated surface. It has no repellant action. Most space sprays contain pyrethrum & DDT or other synthetic insecticides, which are added for synergistic action.

questions.text: The household insecticide used for malaria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malathion Malathion has the least toxicity of all organophosphorous compounds. The technical product is a yellow or clear brown liquid with an unpleasant smell. Commercially, water-dispersible powders are available. Malathion is used in doses of 100-200 mg. per sq. ft., every three months. Because of its low toxicity, malathion has been recommended as an alternative insecticide to DDT. As a low-volume (ULV) spray, malathion has been widely used for killing adult mosquitoes to prevent or interrupt dengue-haemorrhagic fever and mosquito-borne encephalitis epidemics.

questions.text: Following rainfall in an area, the team from the Municipal corporation goes spraying a house to house as a measure for controlling mosquitoes or as an anti-mosquito measure. Which chemical is most likely to be used in it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C Malathion and DDT are commonly used in house spray for anti-mosquito me Areas with a resistance of DDT malathion are used. Malathion and DDT both have residual capacity, resulting in effects for long du DDT has effectiveness for up to 6 to 12 months Malathion has effectiveness for up to three months. Pyrethrum sprays are effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes. Reduction is only temporary due to the absence of residual effect, generally n for household purposes. As reinfestation from outside sources generally occurs within a short time.
